Where is the narration, or where are the stars and what / They forged of decoration in them and of lies?
Conjecture and fabricated tales / Neither of the Nab' tree nor of the Gharb tree when counted.
They judge the matter by them while they are heedless / Of what turned in a sphere of them or in a pole.
Disbelief did not know how many eras lay in wait / For it, the consequences between the brown spears and the cutting swords.
The planning of one holding fast to God, avenging / For God, desiring in God, watchful.
The feeder of victory, his spearheads were not blunt / One day, nor were they veiled from the soul of a veiled one.
He did not shoot a people nor rise to a land / Except an army of terror preceded him.
If he did not lead an army on the day of battle, he would become / From himself alone in a clamorous army.
Far from it! The dignified earth was shaken by him / For a raid of one seeking reward, not a raid of one seeking gain.
He did not spend the gold, which exceeds in its abundance / The pebbles, and by it is poverty to gold.
Indeed the lions, the lions of the forest, their concern / On the day of the hateful is in the robbed, not the robbery.

He also said:
In a position where instant death stood / Glory is found and souls are lost.
Their run cracked in a small band / The water cleared from it and the foam vanished.
From every magnificent one, fate is terrified of him / When he is stripped, neither weak nor denier.
He almost, when he meets the peer out of rage / Before the spearhead, arrives at his soul.
They retreated, but they were good, so they were supported / By an army of patience whose number cannot be counted.
When they saw deaths as a cloud, they wore / From certainty armors that have no rings.
They were far from the nearest screamer, so they have nothing / But swords as help against their enemies.
As for when you lived a day after seeing it / Be proud, for you are the brave knight.
If the fierce lion saw his image / He would not be blamed if he thought, out of terror, that he was the lion.
The spears plundered his spirits when they pointed / No hand repels the doubt of time from him.
As if his soul, from the length of its confusion / Was a watch over itself on the day of battle.
No polytheist woman remained but she knew / That if she did not repent, she bears children for the sword.

He also said:
You see him to the battle the first rider / And under the cloud of death the first dismounter.
He wore a garment of patience and donned / Upon it a sword in the hateful, cutting.
The eagles of his flags shadowed in the morning / Eagles of birds drinking in blood.
They stayed with the banners as if they were / Of the army, except that they did not fight.

He also said:
Whoever is fond of white, full-breasted maidens / I have remained fond of white cutting swords.

He also said:
Their heads on the day of hateful were exchanged from / The spears of backs (spines) to the spears of Rudayna, supported.
I left them as tales; if they were written / Neither paper nor pen would remain on earth.
Then you turned away and did not stay, while / The sky of your justice rained blessings upon them.
If an army were to advance before their resurrection / Your army would have advanced before the resurrection.

He also said:
We have Zaydi, Adadi blazes (marks of fame) / If they rise, the bright stars submit to them.
We have an essence; if it mixed with the earth / Its bellies and backs would become gold.
Our stations are an endowment for knowledge and wisdom / So our beardless one is an elder and our gray-haired one is a scholar.
We softened palms with gifts so they neighbored / The extent of softness, except that our honors are rock.
As if our gifts are related to whoever comes / While no lineage brings him near us nor in-law relationship.
If the decoration of the world turns away from wealth / More decorative than it to us is praise and thanks.
The shelter of orphans in the years (of famine), so whoever / His nest is harsh to his chick, we are a nest for him.
Our destiny refused in generosity anything but nobility / So wealth has no value to us ever.
Hatim ran in a race of it; if / The rain ran in it a heat, it would be said: Which of them is the rain?
A youth whom people stored the world for, and he ceased not / Spending it; so look for whom the store remains.
Whoever wishes, let him boast of what he wishes of dew / For no tribe other than us has that pride.

We gathered height with generosity after its separation / To us, just as the days are gathered by the month.

He also said:
I am the son of those in whom generosity was nursed / And my namesake among them while he was old and young.
Rising stars, towering mountains / Pouring rains, defending swords.
They passed, and it was as if noble deeds with them / Due to the abundance of what they bequeathed of them, were laws.
What hand extended in generosity and did not have / A palm from their generosity and fingers?
They deposited kindness as protected wealth / It was lost, but the deposits were not lost with us.
Masters, if you witnessed the overflow of their palms / You would be certain that provision in the earth is wide.

Al-Buhturi said:
We are those whose hill is not reached / Even if its rank exceeds a boaster.
If the star expressed its virtues / It would not surpass our lineage.

He also said:
That heart was the heart of a peaceful one / Although that dress was the dress of a warrior.
He hastened until he who witnessed the battle said: / Is it a meeting of enemies or a meeting of beloveds?
And a thunderbolt from his decision, by which / Five clouds pour back on the heads of peers.
Dew almost overflows from them onto the enemies / With the sword in the fold of spears and cutting blades.

Abu Al-Tayyib Al-Mutanabbi said:
I pierce horses with their knights over time / Alone, and my speech is not thus while patience is with me.
Braver than me every day is my safety / And it did not persist except that there is a command in itself.
I practiced with calamities until I left them / Saying: Has death died, or did panic panic?
I advanced the advance of the flood as if I / Had other than my soul, or had a revenge with it.
Let the soul take its capacity before its separation / For neighbors separate, and their house is a life span.
Do not think glory is a wineskin and a songstress / For glory is nothing but the sword and the virgin strike.
And striking the necks of kings, and that you see / Black dust clouds and the dragging army.
And your leaving a buzz in the world as if / The ten fingertips of man circulate hearing.
How many mountains I roamed testify that I am / The mountains, and a sea testifies that I am the sea.

He also said:
He visits the enemies in a sky of dust / His spearheads in its sides are stars.
It uncovers him and the swords, as if / Their striking edges, from being notched, are strikers.
They rose as suns and the scabbards were easts / For them, and the heads of men were wests.

He also said:
I have been patient until there is no patience / So now I rush until there is no rusher.
I will leave the faces of the horses grim / And war standing on a leg upon a foot.
With every unsheathed sword that keeps waiting for me / Until I give it turns from the state of servants.
An old man who sees the five prayers as voluntary / And permits the blood of pilgrims in the Sanctuary.
Return the pools of death, O soul, and leave / The pools of fear of death for the sheep and cattle.
If I do not visit you on spears, asking / Then I was not called the son of the mother of glory and generosity.
I will chew the kingdom while the swords are thirsty / And the birds are hungry for meat on a butcher's block.
He who, if he saw me as water, would die of thirst / And if I appeared to him in sleep, he would not sleep.

He also said:
Do calamities take from the likes of me / And does he panic from meeting death?
If time appeared to me as a person / My sword would dye the hair of his parting.

He also said:
My death fears me as if I were its death / And the viper denies me, so my poison kills it.
The long Rudayni spears, my blood breaks them / And the white Surayji swords, my flesh cuts them.

He also said:
They met you with the livers of refusing camels / So you gave them drink, and the edge of the sword was a singer.
You tore the garment of error from them / And dressed them in the garment of guidance.
They did not leave the emirate by choice / Nor did they claim your love out of love.
They did not lower themselves for asceticism in height / Nor were they led out of joy in being led.
But your fear blew in their insides / The blowing of the wind in the leg of the locust.
They died before their death, and when / You bestowed favor, you returned them before the Return.
You sheathed swords which, had they not repented / You would have erased them with them, the erasing of ink.
So let not tongues of clients deceive you / Which hearts of enemies turn.
Be like death, not pitying a weeper / Who weeps because of it, and it quenches while thirsty.
For the wound bleeds after a while / If the building is upon corruption.
And water flows from inanimate rock / And fire comes out of flint.

He also said:

Leavers of the easiest of things / And riders of the difficult of things.
Veiling their horses with white swords, taking / The heads of warriors on their spears as tassels.

He also said:
My time made me taste a trial I choked on / If it tasted it, it would weep as long as it lived and wail.
If I live, I make war a mother / The Samhari spear a brother, and the Mashrafi sword a father.
With every disheveled one meeting death smiling / Until it is as if he has a desire in his killing.
Death is more excusable for me, and righteousness is more beautiful for me / And righteousness is wider, and the world belongs to who conquers.

He also said:
You frighten me with less than what you ordered / And did not know that shame is the worst of consequences.
It is easy for the likes of me, if he seeks a need / The falling of high spears before it and cutting swords.
Much of a man's life is like little of it / It vanishes, and the remainder of his life is like the gone.
Away from me! For I am not one who, if he fears / The bites of vipers, sleeps on scorpions.
To me, by my life, is the intent of every wonder / As if I am a wonder in the eyes of wonders.
In what land have I not dragged my turban / And what place have my mounts not trodden?

He also said:
Take what he came to you with and excuse / For the spoil is in the immediate.
If your year pleased you / Then return to Homs in the coming one.
For the dyed sword with which / You killed is in the hand of the killer.
It frees the captives and enriches the poor / And forgives the ignorant sinner.
So congratulations on the victory He gave you / And may your striving please Him in the future.

He also said:
The highest of kingdoms is what is built on spears / And stabbing, to their lovers, is like kisses.
Swords did not settle in their kingdoms / Until they rattled for a time before in the heads.
Like the Prince, he sought a matter, so it was brought near / By the length of spears and the hands of horses and camels.
And a resolve sent by a Saturn-like ambition / Beneath it, in the place of dust from Saturn.
His spearheads recite the books that executed / And he makes horses substitutes for messengers.
He meets kings and meets nothing but carcasses / And whatever they prepared, he meets nothing but spoils.
The doer of the deed did not do out of his strength / And the sayer of the saying did not leave nor say.
The sender of the army, its dust assassinated / The light of day, so noon became like dusk/baby.
The atmosphere is narrower than what its brightness met / And the eye of the sun in it is the most bewildered of eyes.
He entrusted suspicion with secrets, so were revealed / To him the consciences of the people of the plain and mountain.
He is the brave one counting stinginess as cowardice / And he is the generous one counting cowardice as stinginess.
He returns from every conquest not boasting / While he hastened to it not celebrating.
Time does not protect his desire against him / Nor does armor fortify the soul of the hero.
If I bestowed upon an honor of his, ornaments / I found them on him in the most splendid of ornaments.
In the stupid one, reciting them is harmful / Just as the winds of roses harm the dung beetle.
Every eye has seen you filling it / And tested the best sword as a choice for states.
Enemies do not uncover you out of boredom / From wars, nor opinions out of error.
How many men without land because of their multitude / You left their gathering as land without a man.
Your sword kept running in their blood / Until it walked with you the walk of the drunken drinker.
Indeed happiness is in what you are doing / Successful departing and not departing.
Run the horses on what you were running them on / And take yourself in your first morals.
You did not attack with them except for a victory / Nor did you arrive with them except to a hope.

He also said:
Shall I throw glory off my shoulder and seek it / And leave the rain in my scabbard and seek grass?
The Mashrafiyya (swords) are still honorable / The cure for every noble or they are the pain.
With the army, all masters are defended / And the army is defended by Ibn Abi Al-Hayja.
No country hinders his night travel from a country / Like death, it has no quenching nor satiety.
Until he resided at the outskirts of Kharshana / The Romans, the crosses, and the churches suffer by him.
For captivity what they married, and killing what they bore / And plunder what they gathered, and fire what they sowed.
The birds covet them due to the length of eating them / Until they almost land on their living.
Deaths go early and do not cease standing / Until he says to them 'Return', and they rush away.
Do not think those you captured had a breath of life / For the hyena eats nothing but the dead.

Were they not on the obstacle of the valley when climbed / Lions passing singly, not gathering?
So every invasion against you after this is a remnant / And every invader belonging to Sayf al-Dawla is a follower.
The noble walk on the traces of others / And you create what you come to and innovate.
Whoever is positioned above the place of the sun / Nothing raises him nor lowers him.
Time is apologizing, and the sword is waiting / And their land is for you a summer and spring resort.
I did not praise you in a terror you stood firm for / Until I tested you while heroes were struggling.
A brave man may be thought to be one with stupidity / And a coward may be thought to be one with a tremble.
Indeed, weapons are carried by all people / But not every clawed creature is the Lion.
Would that kings gave according to statuses / Then no base person would have greed with them.

He also said:
Opinion is before the bravery of the brave / It is first, and she (bravery) is the second place.
If they gather in a bitter soul / It attains from height every place.
Perhaps the youth stabbed his peers / With opinion before the stabbing of peers.
Were it not for minds, the lowest lion would be / Closer to honor than man.
When souls differed and managed / The hands of warriors, the high spears.

He also said:
I am more cowardly at the separation of my loved ones / But my soul senses death, so I become brave.
The anger of enemies increases my harshness / And the blame of a friend befalls me, so I panic.

He also said:
Shields for the King of Rum are these letters / He repels with them from himself and distracts.
They are the ample chainmail on him, and their wording / On you is ample praise and virtues.
How did this messenger guide himself in his land / While the dusts I marched in have not settled?
And from what water was he quenching his horses / While watering places did not clear from the mix of blood?

He also said:
My ambition despises every demand / And the long extent falls short in my eye.
I remained at times with my shoulders not moving / Until earthquakes appeared for injustice.
Whoever seeks what I seek of glory and height / Life and death are equal to him.
The leanness of my life is that my dignity be lean / And it is not lean that food be lean.

Al-Mutanabbi said:
Not by my people was I honored, but they were honored by me / And by myself I boasted, not by ancestors.
And with them boasted everyone who spoke the Dad (Arabic) / And the refuge of the criminal and the aid of the expelled.
If I am admired, then it is a wonder of a wonder / Who found above himself no increase.
I am the companion of dew, the master of rhymes / The poison of enemies, and the rage of the envier.
I am in a nation that God corrected / A stranger like Salih in Thamud.

He also said:
I am the rock of the valley when crowded / And if I speak, then I am Gemini.
If I am hidden from the stupid, it is an excuse / That a blind eye does not see me.

He also said:
I am the gold whose assay is known / It increases a Dinar in the casting for the Dinar.

Abu Bakr Al-Khwarizmi said:
On the horses are knights whose sizes are / The feet (steps) of others among the knights.
A people who, when the duelists go out towards them / From their family, they follow them with shrouds.

He also said:
It is strange that they threaten with their multitudes / And he wished they would increase so he could increase in spoils.
If the spy spoke of them with multitude / He judged in the right of the bringer of glad tidings, so he judged (gave reward).

The Judge Ali bin Abdul Aziz Al-Jurjani said:
If aid turns away from you and enemies celebrate / Against you, then declare His name, the One, and overcome.
If white swords were printed on His name / They would penetrate while in the scabbards in every striking place.
The endeavor of a father is not taken off a man / If a polished son does not meet it.

Al-Ghazzi said:
Noble ones, when they ride the horses you think them / Meteors of shooting stars, above them are full moons.

Abu Firas said:
Your army clamored from the length of fighting with it / And the horses and camels complained of you to us.
The Romans knew, when you crossed their land / That neither plain nor mountain protects them.
Every day you visit the gap/frontier; no boredom / Turns you away from it, nor occupation nor weariness.
The soul is striving, the eye is sleepless / The army is engrossed, and the wealth is spent.
Dogs imagined you aiming for other than them / While enemies and occupation surrounded you.
They met you with knights whose reins / Were black veils, saddles, and curtains.
You were the most generous asked and the best / When you gave, so no obligation nor stinginess.

He also said:

More penetrating than the touch of iron and its blade / Abu Wa'il, while time is mutilated, turning its cheek.
He returned while the head of the Qarmatian was before him / Having a body lean from the knuckles of the spear.

He also said:
Is there anyone to convey to the chiefs of my people / And to Sayf al-Dawla, the King, the Hero.
That I did not leave the young women of my people / If they spoke, mumbling speech.
I bought their praise with the sacrifice of my soul / While the fire of war was blazing fiercely.
When I found nothing but fleeing / Worse than death or fate.
I carried my soul to the watering place of death / And said to my companions: Die noble.

He also said:
When the fools of a people tyrannized / We opened a door to war among them.
We granted them plunders, except that we / When they were unjust, we granted them wounds (or wars).
When Sayf al-Din rose, we rose / Just as you agitated angry lions.
He called us while spears were pointed / And we were the answer at his call.
Favors whose maker excelled, so they excelled / And a planting whose planter was good, so it was good.
We were like arrows when they hit / Their targets, for their archer hit.

He also said:
You call generous him who gives his money / But he who gives the noble soul is more generous.
If fleeing does not save from death / In any case, then patience is more hopeful and more decisive.
By my life, you would have been excused if there was an assistant / And you advanced if the battalions advanced.
Why do you not meet the spears with your soul / While you are of the people who are 'They'?
I sought you until I found no seeking place for you / And I advanced until few advance.
No illness sat me down from catching you / But a decree that missed me in you, inevitable.
They bargain with us for ransom regarding you, while we / Hope for you by force, while noses are rubbed in dust.
We will strike them as long as the sword has a cutter / And stab them as long as the spear has a crusher.
If you desire peace, then peace is good / And if you lean towards surrender, then surrender is safer.
I am adragger of every battalion / Accustomed not to have shortness fail it.
I am a descender into every feared place / Looking at its descent with a sidelong glance.
I thirst until the white swords and spears are quenched / And I hunger until the wolf and vulture are full.
O many a house, impregnable, did not frighten me / I rose upon it with death, I and the dawn.
And a tribe, I turned the horses back until I possessed it / Defeated, and veils and covers returned me.
And dragging her tails towards me, I met her / Neither rough meeting met her nor ruggedness.
I returned to her what the whole army possessed / And I returned without a curtain of her houses being uncovered.
What is my need in wealth, seeking its abundance / If I do not save my honor, then may wealth not be abundant.

He also said:
With the tips of the long [spears] / Singular in the middles of heights.
The fruits of glory are never sweet / If the brown spears do not pick them.
Our kingdoms are our earnings whenever / Men inherit them from men.
We must repeat every day / Cheap, with it, are the expensive souls.
If we live, we store them for another / And if we die, then the deaths of men.
Whoever knows wars and practiced them / Pleases the soul with war by turns.
If no fire of mine touches a land / I refuse to warm myself at the fire of another.

He also said:
Did you not see us as the most mighty of people as a neighbor / And the most fertile and most protective of sides?
Ours is the mountain overlooking Nizar / We settled its highland and hills.
People favor us and we do not shy away / And we are described with beauty and not favored (unjustly).
Rabi'a, nay Nizar, has known / That we are the head and people are the tails.

He also said:
A man is where he places himself / And I am placing it above the two bright stars.
Wasting of wealth, gathering of praise / Leaving of evil, doer of good.
Why do I not spend the evening and morning while in my hand / Are the precious moneys of men, the noble ones?
We have the end of the matter which in its beginnings / The necks of enemies and shoulders stretch.
Our young ones in noble deeds are elders / Our last ones in feats are firsts.
If I attack, I find no attacker against me / And if I say a saying, I find no one to argue.

He also said:
My horses, even if their benefit is great / Between the swords and the bleeding spears.
My noble deeds are the number of stars, and my home / Is the refuge of the noble and the home of guests.

I do not acquire equipment for the changes of my time / Until it is as if its calamities are my allies.
Traits I was known by when I was a youth / And I knew the likes of them in my ancestors.

He also said:
The chiefs of the tribe knew that we / Ours is the mountain, protected on its two sides.
The desiring ones return to its shade / And the fearful take refuge in its peak.

He also said:
If people were created for sipping a cup / And flute and tambourine and lute.
Then the sons of Hamdan were not created except / For glory, or for might, or for generosity.

Abu Firas said:
We have a house on the neck of the Pleiades / Distant in the paths of ropes, high.
Knights shade it with high spears / And maidens spread it with food.

Abu Al-Asha'ir Al-Hamdani said:
O brother of knights, if you saw my positions / While the horses thrash under the knights.
You would have read from them what the hand of war writes / While white swords vowelize and spears dot.

Abu Zuhair said:
The tribes of Ya'rub and the two sons of Nizar / Have known what they met from us.
We met them with long spears / Giving them glad tidings of short lives.

Abu Nasr said:
If I wished, I would teach noble deeds my character / But I am gentle with noble deeds.
I fear for them that they might give up their soul / If a strait comes to them in time.

Dhu Al-Kifayatayn said:
The humiliation of defeat humiliated them, so bent / The spine of the back, and the neck veins straightened.
Wearing dyed clothes was a habit for them / So the cutting swords sewed for them from it.
You were arrogant, so you flew, and the stick is a rebuke for who disobeyed / And the slave of disgrace stands with disgrace, beneficial.
I smiled while the noble horses were frowning / And I advanced while the thin white swords were rushing.
I cracked the night of their gatherings with the morning of victory / And how can the night remain when the morning is cracking?
Victory is not bending, nor is victory forsaking / Nor is the blade treacherous, nor is the arrow rising (missing).

Sheikh Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Al-Hasan bin Abi Al-Tayyib Al-Bakharzi recited for Prince Ali bin Muhammad Al-Sulayhi, rising in Hijaz:
My saddle is my bed and the sword is my bedfellow / And my war equipment is not those with anklets.
My spear hands me the distant because I / Took what wearied the taker.
I have an ambition that rises above every ambition / And I have a hope that wearied every hoper.
I have from Banu Qahtan supporters of a state / Patricians from the heroes of all tribes.

Al-Hasan bin Yahya Al-Hakkak Al-Makki answered him:
Slowly! Truth is not negated by falsehood / Nor is one serious in matters like a joker.
Like your claim that armor is your dress in battle / And that is for cowardice in you, not virtues.
Does the sword benefit its bedfellow a day / If a brave one does not share the bed with wakefulness?
Why did you not take patience as armor and shield / Just as patience is my shield in descending lines?
You boast that you became the hope of a band / So fie on a hoped one and fie on a hope.
Is it except in an inheritance you gathered / Why did it not become the giving of favor and gift?
Just as our concern, know, is aiding a beggar / And helping a distressed one and enriching a poor one.
Do not be deceived by the lion at his lairs / How many a hiding one surprised with the leap of an attacker.

Al-Farazdaq said:
We have the unyielding might and the number which / If pebbles are counted, swears (it is more).
You see them sitting around it and their eyes / Broken, their sights do not turn.
And two houses: The House of God, we are its guardians / And a house at the top of Ilya (Jerusalem), high.
We see people, when we march, marching behind us / And if we nod to the people, they stop.
There is no might except our might is conqueror over it / And the humiliated asks us for fairness, so we are fair.
Thousands of thousands of men and of spears / And horses like the prime of locusts and rough terrain.
If they are tempted one day, we strike their heads / For the religion until the one reconciled accepts.
He who rivaled Tamim will know, when / His legs fall in the sea, who stays behind.
Sa'd is the mountains of might, and the sea is Malik / So no nursling wears out nor is the sea depleted.
When Darim gathers for me at a goal / I run to it the run of one who takes the side.
Sa'd is like the people of the Dam (Gog and Magog); if opened upon them / They would surge like locusts surge and roam.
They balance the earth; were it not for them, it would wrap / Over the people or almost tilt and dry up.

He also said:
He offers hundreds the decayed bones of Ghalib / So he strove with them, and the releaser of every captive.
And the one sought for help; so not like his ropes / Are the ropes of a protector for the one seeking refuge.

The tribes knew that we are their lords / And the most worthy of them of the rituals of Takbir.
Our Lord placed Prophethood and Caliphate / In us, and the Mosque of His Inhabited House.
Is there anyone like them... for his people / ... those noble deeds all of them with the pebbles / Except a little for us and...
From us is the Prophet Muhammad... / Blindness with a commanded truthful one.
Prophethood, Caliphate, and Guidance are / In us, and the first who called for appearance.
The best of those who passed and who is to be / With the clear verses, a bringer of glad tidings and a warner.

Jarir said:
Did you not see me drawing my arrow / Whomever I shoot, my arrows do not miss his killing spots.
I kindled my fire with iron, so it became / Having a glare; whoever prays (approaches) it is burnt by God.

Abu Al-Qasim Al-Zahi said:
The night becomes light from my thought / And the sword melts in shame from my look.
And the horses, if I loaded them with my knowledge of them / I would leave them as dust under the dust clouds.
I count the sins against my time with an eye / Whose tears possess no counting.

Taj al-Dawla Abu Al-Hussein Ahmad bin Adud al-Dawla said:
I am the jeweled crown on the forehead of / Kingdoms, walking the paths of righteousness.
Our battalions, victory shines in us / With banners embroidered with success.
Kingdoms of horizons almost become a market / Driving to me from all directions.
Indeed, to God belongs my honor, preserved / Glory protected it with permissible wealth.

Abu Nasr Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad bin Nubata said:
And a deceived one tries to attain my honor / So I said to him: The stars are not attained.
He sees in noble deeds the overflow of my palm / And claims that it is the going of the gift.
He wonders that I contained virtue as a child / Indeed, to God, then to me, belongs perfection.
I carry, with the weakness of my body, the weight of my soul / And my soul, mountains do not carry it.
I hear every saying other than my saying / So I know that it is nonsense and impossible.

Ibn Lu'lu' said:
All traits of height are from my traits / And the pouring of rain is a drop from my north (or left hand).
My soul purifies me from base matters / And calls me to high matters.
For my might is the length of my hand and the sword / And for glory and praise are my status and wealth.

Abu Al-Hasan Al-Mousawi, the Naqib, said:
Ours is the high tree for which / The branches of the good ancestors pulled towards glory.
If its roots are in the atmosphere of the sky / Then where are its high branches and where are the peaks?

Abu Al-Fath Al-Busti said:
We are people who do not submit to an unjust one / Against us, nor are we pleased with the judgment of a deviate.
We possessed high matters with high spears, so our neighbor / Is mighty, and he whom we sponsor is not fearful.
We inherited from the fathers at their cutting off (death) / Broad swords that suffice instead of the drawings of books.
Our swords and spears command us / If the banner of Caliphs does not command us.
We built a Kaaba with the tips of spearheads / So the kings of sects circumambulated it by force.
Whoever wishes let him be rough, and whoever wishes let him be soft / For we do not pay cash if they loan us with counterfeit.
We will repay the people of kindness with kindness / And give instant poison to the people of hatred.

The Chapter of Hamasah is completed by the hand of its writer with the praise of God and His good success.

Chapter Two: Literature, Wisdom, and Proverbs

Abu Tammam recited for Miskin Al-Darimi:
Youths of truth, I do not inform some of them / Of the secret of others, except that I bring them together.
For every man has a branch of the heart empty / And a place of secret talk whose disclosure is not desired.
They remain scattered in the lands, and their secret / Is at a rock whose cracking wearied men.

Al-Murrar bin Saeed said:
If you wish one day to lead a clan / Then lead with forbearance, not with haste and insults.
Forbearance is better, know this, as an outcome / Than ignorance, unless you are stubborn out of injustice.

Shabib bin Al-Barsaa Al-Murri said:
I am a leaver of grudge; its moist earth appeared / From the client, so I do not stir it up.
Fearing that it might commit a crime against me, for / Small matters excite big ones.
The ends of matters become clear when they pass / And their fronts approach looking like them.
If Sa'd bin Dhubyan boasts, they will not find / Other than what we built, what their boaster counts.
Did you not see that we are the light of Qaww, and only / The light becomes clear to people in the darkness.

Iyas bin Al-Qa'if said:
Rich men stay in their land / And distance throws the destitute to shooting places.
So honor your brother over time as long as you are together / Death is sufficient as separation and distance.

If you visit a land after long avoidance / You lost my friend, and the lands are as they are.

Salem bin Wabisa Al-Asadi said:
I love the youth who denies indecencies his hearing / As if he has a deafness to every indecency.
Sound of the motives of the chest, not spreading harm / Nor preventing good, nor speaking obscenity.
If you wish to be called noble, honored / Polite, witty, wise, glorious, free.
When a slip appears from a friend of yours / Be you devising an excuse for his slip.
The richness of the soul is what suffices you to fill a need / For if it increases a thing, that richness returns as poverty.

Al-Mu'ammil bin Umayl Al-Muharibi said:
How many a mean person wished that I insulted him / Even if my insult in him is bitterness and colocynth.
But refraining from insulting the mean out of honor / Is more harmful to him than his insult when he is insulted.

Aqil bin Ullafa Al-Murri said:
Be the smartest of the smart if you are among them / And if you are among the fools, be you a fool.
Time has garments, so be in its garments / As you wore it one day, new and worn.

Malut bin Badal Al-Quray'i said:
Whenever people see the rich man while his neighbor / Is poor, they say: Incapable and strong (or industrious).
Richness and poverty are not from the trick of the youth / But are shares divided and lucks.
If man is wearied by chivalry as a youth / Its pursuit when old is difficult for him.
How many a rich man we saw blamed / And a vagabond of a people died while praised.

Adi bin Zaid Al-Ibadi said:
You do not know when a beggar comes / Are you, by what you give him, or is he happier?
Perhaps a beggar with a need, if you prevented him / From a request today, will have a tomorrow.
In the multitude of hands is a deterrent for the ignorant / And forbearance is more lasting for men and more returning.

Another said:
Beware of the matter which, if its resources / Expand, its sources narrow on you.
It is not good that a man excuses himself / While he has no excuser among the rest of the people.

Al-Abbas bin Mirdas said:
You see the thin man and despise him / While in his clothes is a roaring lion.
And the plump one pleases you so you test him / And the plump man fails your thought.
The greatness of men is not by pride for them / But their pride is generosity and good.
The Bughath birds (small birds) are most numerous in chicks / And the mother of the hawk is barren, scarce.
The weak birds are longest in bodies / And neither the hawks nor the falcons are long.
The camel became great without a mind / So the camel did not dispense with the bone.
The boy turns him in every direction / And the rope confines him to humiliation.
And the slave girl hits him with sticks / So there is no change (jealousy/anger) in him nor denial.
If I am little among your evil ones / I am great among your good ones.

Another said:
Do not interfere in a matter whose affairs are sufficed / And do not advise except him who accepts it.
Do not forsake the client when a calamity / Befalls, and engage in battle him who fights him.
Do not deprive the noble client, for he is / Your brother, and you do not know, perhaps you will ask him.

Another said:
I turn away from foods that I desire / So I leave them while in my belly is a folding (hunger).
No, by your father, there is no good in life / Nor the world if modesty goes.
Man lives with good as long as he is shy / And the stick remains as long as the bark remains.

Salem bin Wabisa said:
And a slanderer from the bad clients, possessing envy / Feeding on my flesh, and it does not cure him of craving.
I treated a chest for a long time concealing hatred / From him, and I clipped fingernails without clippers.
With prudence and good I do to him and mend him / Fear of God and what he did not observe of my kinship.
So his bow became strung against me / Shooting my enemy openly, not hiding.
Indeed, from forbearance is a humiliation you know / And forbearance with ability is a virtue of generosity.

Some of the Banu Asad said:
I become rich so richness does not make me reckless / And I offer my ease to who seeks my loan.
I become hard sometimes, so my hardship intensifies / And I attain the ease of richness while I have my honor.
Possessor of trust in me did not attain it until it cleared and shone / With a loan or an obligation.
I give my favor and my character clears / When the morals of every pure youth become turbid.
But it is the flow of God and my journey / And my tightening the belts of the mount to the goal.
I save the client from the matter after / He slips as the camel slips from the slippery place.
I grant him my money, my love, and my victory / Even if he is bending the ribs on hatred of me.

Another said:
I forget at every anger / If it is said 'Your client', the bearing of grudges.

Even if he is a client not, in what befalls me / Of the matter, sufficient nor assisting.

Hatim bin Abdullah Al-Tai said:
I am not one to strive by the virtue of its rein / To drink the water of the basin before the riders.
Nor am I one to fold the bag of her saddle / To send her light and leave my companion.
If you are the master of the young camel, do not let / Your companion walk behind her not riding.
Make her kneel and let him ride behind; if she carries you both / Then so be it, and if it is punishment, then punish.

Al-Kindi said:
I am abstinent from many foods / When hunger decorates indecency to the soul.

Urwa bin Al-Ward said:
Let me roam in the lands, perhaps I / Will gain wealth in which there is support for the possessor of right.
Is it not great that a calamity befalls / And we have no reliability in rights?

Another said:
Your brother is he whom if you call for a calamity / He answers you, and if you get angry at the sword, he gets angry.

Malik bin Harim Al-Hamdani said:
I was informed, and days are possessors of experiments / And days show you what you do not know.
That abundance of wealth benefits its owner / And praises him, while he is blameworthy.
And that little wealth is spoiling for a man / He is sheared as the protected herd is sheared.
He sees degrees of glory he cannot reach / And sits in the middle of people not speaking.

Muhammad bin Bashir said:
That I push along during nakedness with worn clothes / And suffice from much provision with a little hanging thing.
Is better and more noble than that I see favors / Tied by mean people on my neck.
I, even if my means fall short of my ambition / And my money is not strong enough for my character.
Am leaving every matter that would stick / Shame to me, and make me drink in the murky watering hole.

He also said:
What burdens you of morning and night journeys / Land at times, and at times you ride the deep seas?
How many a youth whose step fell short in provision / You found him winning with the arrows of provision.
Indeed matters, if their paths are blocked / Patience opens from them all that was locked.
Do not despair, even if a demand is long / If you seek help with patience, that you see relief.
The possessor of patience is worthy to attain his need / And the addict of knocking on doors to enter.
Estimate for your leg before the step its place / For whoever rises on a slippery place out of heedlessness slips.
Let not a clarity you are drinking deceive you / For perhaps it was mixed with turbidity.
See for your leg before the step its place / For whoever rises on a slippery place out of heedlessness slips.

Hassan bin Thabit said:
I protect my honor with my money, I do not soil it / May God not bless money after honor.
I scheme for money if it perishes so I earn it / But I am not a schemer for honor if it creates fire (perishes).

Al-Muqanna' Al-Kindi said:
My people blame me for debt, but / My debts are in things that earn them praise.
I block with it what they vacated and wasted / Of gaps of rights they could not block.
Indeed, that which is between me and the sons of my father / And between the sons of my uncle is very different.
If they eat my flesh, I save their meat / And if they destroy my glory, I build glory for them.
If they waste my absence, I protect their defects / And if they fall from me, I fall for them in guidance.
If they rebuke birds with bad omen passing me / I rebuke birds passing them for good omen.
I do not bear ancient hatred against them / The leader of the people is not one who bears hatred.
They have the bulk of my money if richness follows me / And if my money is little, I do not burden them with aid.
I am the slave of the guest as long as he is staying / And I have no trait other than it resembling the slave.
However, my people, no onlooker sees / Like their gray hair gray hair, nor their beardless beardless.
With virtue, dreams (minds), generosity, and sovereignty / My people are spring in time when it is severe.

A man from Fazara said:
If my bone is not long, then I / Am reaching with good traits.
There is no good in the beauty of bodies and their nobility / If minds do not weigh the beauty of bodies.
If I am among the tall people, I exceed them / With a favor, until it is said: Tall.
How many we have seen of many branches / Dying if roots do not revive them.
I have not seen like kindness; as for its taste / It is sweet, and as for its face, it is beautiful.

Abdullah bin Muawiya bin Abdullah Al-Talibi said:
I see my soul yearning for matters / And my money falls short of reaching them.
So my soul does not obey me with stinginess / And my money does not reach my actions.

Al-Mutawakkil Al-Laythi said:
I, when the friend initiates for me / A cutting, or cut the purity or severed.

I do not sip his water on murkiness / Nor does he see me panicking for his separation.
I abandon him, then the dust of abandonment / Ends from me, and I did not say obscenity.
Beware the connection of the mean, for he has / A bite when the rope of his connection is cut.

Qais bin Al-Khatim said:
Some residence in homes / Where a youth is humiliated is nothing but a trial.
Man wants to be given his desire / And God refuses except what He wills.
Every hardship that befalls a people / After its severity, ease will come.
The greedy is not given richness for greed / And wealth may grow upon generosity.
The rich of soul, as long as it lives, is rich / And the poverty of the soul, as long as it lives, is misery.
Wealth is not beneficial to the miser / Nor is generosity disgraceful to its owner.
Some disease has a sought cure / And the disease of stupidity has no cure.

Yazid bin Al-Hakam admonishing his son Badr:
O Badr, and proverbs appear / For the possessor of core (mind), the wise.
Blame for the friend in his love / What good is a love that does not last?
Know for your neighbor his right / And the right is known by the noble.
Know that the guest one day / Will praise or blame.
People are two builders: A praised / Of building or a blameworthy.
Know, my son, for it is / By knowledge the knowledgeable benefits.
Indeed matters, their small / Is what excites the great.
Oppression throws down its people / And injustice, its grazing is unwholesome.
Sometimes the distant is for you / A brother, and the intimate cuts you off.
Man is honored for richness / And the destitute is humiliated for lack.
The pious resourceful may fail / And the sinful fool may increase.
This is given respite and that is tested / So which of them is the wronged?
Man is stingy in rights / And for the distant heirs what he grazes.
What is the stinginess of him who is for death / And its doubt a stoned target?
He sees the centuries before him / They subsided as the dry grass subsided.
The world is ruined, so no / Misery lasts nor bliss.

Munqidh Al-Hilali said:
What life is my life if I am from it / Between settling and imminent departure?
Every ravine of the lands, as if I am / Seeking some of its people for revenge.
I see virtue and honor only / As your restraining the soul from seeking excesses.
It is a trial to carry favors, even if / You hear from us 'You are given it by a giver'.

Muhammad bin Abi Shahadh said:
If you are given wealth then do not give generously / With the surplus of wealth, you will find your money praised.
If you do not rub with your side some of what / Is suspicious from the near, the distant will shoot you.
If forbearance does not overcome ignorance for you, you will cease not / To have many lightnings and thunders against you.
If determination does not open doubt for you, you will cease not / To be led as the led horse is followed by a leader.
Little use from you is money you gathered / If it becomes an inheritance and dirt covers you.

Al-Hakam bin Abdal said:
I seek what the noble seeks of provision / With my soul, and I make the seeking beautiful.
I milk the flowing pure one and do not / Strain the teats of other than it in milking.
I saw the noble youth / His desire in loss is a desire.
The slave does not seek height nor / Does he give you a thing unless he fears.
Like the donkey with bad saddle sores / Does not do anything well unless beaten.
I did not find the bond of characters anything but / Religion, when I considered, and lineage.
The low resident may be provided while he did not / Tighten a saddle to a camel nor a hump.
And the possessor of the mount is deprived of wealth / And the journey, he who ceases not to be a stranger.

Al-Saltan Al-Abdi said:
The turning of morning and the passing of evening / Aged the small and annihilated the large.
If a night aged its day / There came after that a young day.
We go and come for our needs / And the need of who lives does not end.
The needs of a man die with him / And a need remains for him as long as he remains.
If I said one day to whom you see / Show me the noble, they showed you the rich.
Did you not see Luqman advised his sons / And I advised Amr, so what a good executor.
My son, the deceit of men's secret talk appeared / So be, at your secret, the deceit of the savior.
Your secret is what was with one person / And the secret of three is not hidden.

Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Azdi said:
I do not push the cousin walking on a brink / Even if the calamities of his harm reached me.
But I console him and forget his sins / So the returners may return him to me one day.
Enough for you of humiliation and bad deed / Is antagonizing the relative, even if he is called a cutter.

Ubayy bin Hamam Al-Absi said:
I am not a master of a shameful deed to be called to it / For shameful matters have masters.
People, neither the friend nor the enemies, will find / My skin weak when they bite my skin.
My lineage, O Ibn Ghanm, is different / From the lineage of the mean, so seek me behind me.
It is equal to me that I die or that I see / Like a few men who settle on disgraces.
I am not fearful of him who does not fear me / Nor do I see for a man what he does not see for me.
If a man does not love you except unwillingly / Like the refusal of the she-camel to nurse, that is not lasting.

Some of the Banu Faq'as said:
Possessors of grudges showing enmity / Ulcerated of hearts, accustomed to lies.
I forgot their hatred and left them / While they are, when the friend is mentioned, enemies.
So that I prepare them for one further than them / And indeed one comes to possessors of hatred.

Another said:
Let not the ease of life in comfort prevent you / The yearning of a soul for family and homelands.
You find in every land, if you settle in it / A family for a family, and neighbors for neighbors.

A man from Banu Asad said:
I am not the base, mean one, nor the one who / If the possessor of affection turns away from me, I become destitute.
But if he lasts, I last; and if there is / For him a way away from me, I have a way away from him.
Indeed, the best love is a love volunteered / By the soul, not a love that came while tired.

Another said:
There is no good in the love of a man compelled / Towards you, nor in a companion you do not agree with.
If a man does not offer of love the like of what / You offered him, then know that I am separating from him.

Jabir bin Al-Thalab Al-Tai said:
Whoever is poor among his people praises richness / Even if he was among them the center of the necklace, a maternal uncle.
Lack of wealth disgraces the mind of a man / Even if he was more traveling than men and more cunning.
As if the youth was never naked when he clothed himself / And was never a vagabond when he became wealthy.
And was never in misery if he spent a night / Flirting with a gazelle, languid of eye, kohl-eyed.

Another said:
By my life, the group of a man is better as protection / For him, even if they raised him on every mount.
From the furthest side, even if he was of wealth / Abundant; and no one informs you like an experienced one.
If you are among a people and are not of them / Then eat what you are fed of bad and good.
If the soul tells you that you are capable / Of what the hands of men contained, then try.

Urwa bin Al-Ward Al-Absi said:
I say to a people in the shelter: Go / In the evening we spent at Mawan, emaciated.
Attain richness or reach with your souls / To a resting place from a painful death.
Whoever is like me, possessing dependents and destitute / Of wealth, throws himself into every throwing place.
To reach an excuse or hit a desire / And the reaching of a soul to its excuse is like success.

Aws bin Habna Al-Timi said:
If a man gives you humiliation, then give him / Humiliation, even if the bonds are close.
If you are unable to humiliate him / Then leave him until the day you are able.
And approach if you have no trick / And be determined if you are certain you are hamstrung.

Iyas bin Al-Art Al-Tai said:
If an hour is delayed, make it / For good, for time is crooked, possessing riot.
If there is good or there is some rest / Then you will meet worries and distress.

Sawwar bin Al-Mudharrib said:
O heart, does an admonition forbid you / Or does the length of time create forgetfulness for you?
I will cover what the possessor of mind covers / Of need, and kill the secret with concealment.
A need without another that appeared / I made it for the one I hid a title.
I am as if I see him who has no modesty / And no trust among people, naked.

Another said:
Not the youth of youths is he whose main concern / Is a morning drink, and if he spends the evening, the surplus of an evening drink.
But the youth of youths is he who goes or comes / To harm an enemy or to benefit a friend.

Sheikh Abu Al-Hussein Ahmad bin Faris recited in his Hamasah for Mus'ab bin Al-Zubair:
Among the people is one holding fast to the strength of his command / And a negligent one whom negligence disgraced.
Do not accept the station of the humiliated and do not stay / In a house of incapacity while you are experienced.
If you intend, execute your intent; indeed / Seeking needs is all a chastisement.

Al-Ajda' bin Khashram said:
If you fear a blocking of a matter, throw with determination / Its paths; determination will ride a mount with you.
If a direction blocked its openings against you / You will inevitably find a way out.

God did not make matters, when they befall / On you, a locked gate that cannot be sought.
Be a sturdy man when / The daughters of time turn against him, he turns.
Men are blamed before testing their time / And how is a man blamed until he tries?
I am indeed an avoider, little is my exposure / To the face of a man one day if he avoids.
I am not the forgetter of the friend if / The house is near, nor the weeper if he is absent.

A man from Jurm said:
The mixture (partners/neighbors) separated, and I did not separate out of hate / The near one, O Umaym, is not like the one who is far.
Indeed the lover, if his covenant becomes old / Forgets the beloved, and weariness consoles his need.
Worry, if you do not execute it to its path / Is sufficient company as trouble for the youth.
Poverty disgraces the youth among his people / And the eye, the noble one hurts it over the mote.
Wealth extends the tongue of the mean / Until he is as if he were a king seen.
Prevent your honor from enemies, do not be / Fat for its eater, bought with a stick.
Do not eat the client if you quarrel with him / One day, for you would be making enemies rejoice at him.
If you forbid people from a character, be / Like the leaver of the character he forbade.

Al-A'war Al-Shanni said:
Amira knew that my neighbor / When the fruitful one is stingy, is of my dependents.
And I am not stingy against a cousin / With my victory in calamities nor with my money.
I am not a sayer of a saying to gain favor / With a saying my deeds do not verify.
What falling short? Ma'add has known / And the morals of lowliness are among my traits (sarcastic/negated).
If I attain richness, I do not exceed in it / Nor do I single out the clients with my roughness.
I did not cut off a brother for a witty brother / Nor did the witty one blame my connection.
I have become not needing, in what / I tested of matters, to ask.

Another said:
By your life, you do not know what the night brings / Upon you, and you do not know what is in the unseen.

Habnaqa Al-Qaisi said:
If you sought the earth and it became distant / Against you, then put down the saddle of the mount and dismount.
Do not mix in it, for you will reach / By gentle night travel in it and wise dismounting.
If you are in a house whose people humiliate you / And you are not shackled in it, then move.
If you are of little money, do not be / Adhering to the bottom of the house as long as you are not wealthy.

Qais bin Amr bin Malik said:
I am a man who rarely praises anyone / Until I see some of what he does and leaves.
Do not praise a man until you test him / And do not blame him whom the news did not test.

Abu Al-Nasr Al-Asadi said:
My wife informs me about life as if she / Informs me of the matter I am ignorant of.
The youth lives with poverty for a day and with richness / And each is as if he did not meet it when it leaves him.

Al-Samma bin Abdullah Al-Qushayri said:
O blamer, lessen the blame, indeed my death / Is a decree of nights that have no increase.
Indeed my departure does not bring my death closer / Nor does it prevent me from dying while sitting.
God may return the youth after his absence / And others meet deaths as witnesses.

Ziyad bin Zaid said:
A man who has tested time does not fear / The turning of its two eras (night and day), for he is not wise (if he fears).
Do not despair of time for the connection of a hater / Nor feel safe from time for the cutting of a beloved.
Whatever is coming is not far, so it falls / Nor is what passed of joy near.
Everything that comes, you are related to it / And you are not related to a thing that has passed.

Rabi'a bin Ubayd Al-Qa'nabi (Abu Dhu'ab) said:
Death is going with the youths / Even if they protect themselves with swords and armor.
Do not make worry a sickness that has no relief / Let us not find boredom, narrow of arm.

Hajjaj bin Allat Al-Sulami said:
I befriend men, I do not inform some of them / Of the secret of others; indeed my chest is wide for it.
My chest ribs met over a decisive heart / Concealing of what his ribs enclosed.

Another said:
Why should I perpetuate patience for a father of humility / While neither provision is forbidden nor am I restricted?
Perhaps patience was humiliation / And led to the matter that is uglier.

Al-Alaa Al-Hadrami (The Prophet, peace be upon him, asked him to recite, so when he recited his poetry, the Prophet said: Indeed, some speech is magic, and some poetry is wisdom) said:
Greet the possessors of grudges, your greeting / Captivates their hearts, the lowest; for the bad leather may be raised.
If they crawl with hate, forgive out of generosity / And if they withdraw the talk from you, do not ask.

For what hurts you is hearing it from him / And what they said behind you was not said.

Amr bin Al-Aas, may God be pleased with him, said:
If a man does not leave food he loves / And forbid a straying heart where it aimed.
He fulfills a desire from it and leaves a shame / If you mention the likes of it, it fills the mouth.
If I do not praise a truthful one with kindness / And do not blame the base, mean, blameworthy one.
Then why did I know good and evil by name / And God split for me the hearing and the mouth?
If my money is little or I am hit by a calamity / ... my life chastity and generosity.
I turn away from the possessor of wealth until it is said to me / 'This one has created pride and arrogance.'
I have no pride or bad care / But it is my action when I was...

Ibn Harma said:
If you do not take from people a protection / With which you tighten the fingers in your palms.
You will drink on the roads of water where you find it / On murkiness, and ambitions will enslave you.
I surely wear the dress narrow / And leave wearing the dress while the dress is wide.
I turn my mount away from some waters / When some men admire the watering places.

Another said:
I choose modesty over richness / And drinking pure water with cold pure milk.
I wear the cloak of trial while I see / The place of ease if I exposed my honor to it.

Another said:
I fold the belly without filling it / When the winds of winter, the storms, blow.
Fearing that I be called big-bellied, while / The riders of the submissive mounts have gone early blaming me.

Another said:
I help my brother or my companion in his trial / I stand when time bites and I sit.
Whoever singles out brothers in what befalls them / The nights alert him once while he is single.

Hazn bin Janab Al-Tamimi said:
Do not oppose evil without its people / If you are free from its passion, isolated.
Whoever protects the honors of men with his honor / Permits a forbidden thing of his parents and is ignorant.
Do not be of those whom worry closes his knowledge / Upon him with a locked latch of evil.
Do not make the wide earth its place / A path for you, rugged of movement.
If you fear humiliation from a house, turn it / To other than you, and move from the house of harm.
Man is only where he places himself / So place yourself in righteous deeds.

Another said:
I see you blaming days and time / And time has an excuse if you sought an excuse for it.
Time is not the perpetrator of a thing you hate / Nor the bringer of trial, so do not insult time.
But whenever God sends His command / Upon a group, He turns their hardships into ease.

Haritha bin Badr Al-Ghudani said:
You were moved by a tray (of drinks/food) and you almost did not move / Foolishly, and you have tested among those who test.
You tested: What is life but a distraction / And time is nothing but a waterwheel that turns.
Today is nothing like yesterday which passed / And like tomorrow coming, and all will go.

Abdul Aziz bin Zurara said:
What is the mind of the wise without luck / Richer in livelihood than a wick?
I saw luck cover every defect / And far are lucks from minds.

A man said:
Whoever accompanies days blames a companion / And accompanies blamers, and time disciplines him.
I become rich so richness expands me / And hardship contracts me from him who advances me.

Abu Al-Minhal said:
A man is nothing—so let his beginning be what it was— / Even if he affects character, except like what he was created.

For some of Banu Asad:
Wear your companion if his morals become obscene / And do not be, at obscenity, reckless, hasty.
I wore my people on what was of character / And there is no new for him who does not wear the old.
The most poetic verse you are saying / Is a verse said when you recite it: 'Truth'.
Poetry is only the core of man which he displays / To the councils, whether smartness or stupidity.

Some of Banu Asad said:
A generic mind and a forbearance without defect / Prevent me from oppressing a relative.
If he softens, I soften; and if his scorpions crawl / I fill his hands with forgiveness and generosity.

Al-Mazrad said:
I am a wearer, against hatred and loathing / Of cousins, among them a hater and an envious one.
I defend and throw pebbles from behind them / And start with kindness to them and return.

Abu Hilal Al-Hasan bin Abdullah Al-Askari in his Hamasah for Al-Khalil:
The best of God's division for a man is his mind / There is nothing of goods that approaches it.

If the Merciful completes a man's intellect / Then his morals and nature are complete.
The youth lives by intellect among people; indeed / Upon intellect run his knowledge and experiences.
Whoever is victorious by intellect and bravery / Then the possessor of luck in the matter of livelihood overcomes him.
The soundness of his intellect adorns the youth among people / Even if his earnings are restricted.
And the lack of his intellect disgraces him among people / Even if his roots and lineages are noble.

Ma'n bin Aws said:
By your life, I did not extend my hand for suspicion / Nor did my foot carry me towards an indecency.
Nor did my hearing or sight lead me to it / Nor did my opinion or intellect guide me to it.
I know that no calamity befell me / From time, except that it befell a youth before me.
I am not walking, as long as I live, to a scene / Of a matter which the likes of me should not strive for.
Nor do I prefer myself over a relative / And I prefer my guest, as long as he stays, over my family.

Mudris bin Rab'i Al-Asadi said:
Do not destroy the soul with blame and regret / Over a thing whose capability is blocked to other than you.
Do not despair of a good thing that you may attain / Even if it is a snatching between hands racing for it.
What has passed, leave it when it is difficult, and be patient / With time if its calamities turn against you.
For you do not give a man the luck of another / Nor do you know the precedence of which the rain pours.

Yahya bin Talib said:
What makes me disinterested at every time in doing favors / To people is what I tested of little gratitude.
If you do not count yourself as being alone / The hateful will surround you from where you do not know.

Ibn Jadhal Al-Ta'an said:
And a client called by oppression, and oppression is like its name / And for death there are causes that stray from prudence.
He called me to kindle the war between me and him / So I said to him: No, rather come to peace.
Beware of war, for I do not have its leather / Sound, and it ceases not to come despite dislike.
If you win the war, you are of them / And you return with palms full of spoils.
And I must kill you, perhaps you are of them / Otherwise, a wound that is not on the bone.
When he came, I released the surplus of his cloak / Upon him, so he did not return with prudence or determination.
He was the fallen of the horses at the first moment / So away with him, a chooser of ignorance over knowledge.

Another said:
If you wish to be insulted among a people / Even if you are the refined and the core.
Every possessor of lineage and religion fears you / But among the mean, you will not be feared.

Qais bin Al-Khatim said:
I am the most independent of people from an affecter / Who sees people as straying while he is not guided.
Wealth and morals are nothing but borrowed / So whatever you can of their good, take as provision.
Whenever you lead the truth with falsehood, it refuses / And if you lead the firm mountains with truth, they follow.
If you come to a matter from other than its door / You go astray, and if you enter from the door, you are guided.

Al-Asma'i said:
I have not seen an intellect complete except... / And I have not seen knowledge complete except with manners.
I have not seen in things when I tested them / An enemy to the core of a man more hostile than anger.
I have not seen between hardship and ease a mixture / And I have not seen between the living and the dead any lineage.

Haritha bin Badr Al-Ghudani said:
If worry becomes a disease, then execute it / You are not executing it while you are blaming it.
Do not descend the matter of severity upon a man / If he seeks a matter, his blamers hinder him.
If you kill a thing with knowledge, then speak by it / And beware of the matter of which you are ignorant.
And say to the heart if a leap leaps at you / Of fear: Calm down, most fear is false.
Do not entrust a secret to a non-concealer / Lest you sit, if he spreads it against you, arguing with him.
I see wealth as the retreating of shadows; sometimes / It returns, and other times the snarer snares the wealth.

A Bedouin said:
When they saw my wealth had approached its flow / They threw the arrow of hatred at me from every side.
I became despicable to him whom I used to think / I was noble to, before the befalling of calamities.

Al-Asma'i said:
Your friend when you are rich is many / But you have no friend in your poverty.
So do not get angry at anyone if / He folds away the visit from you during distress.

Al-Uqayshir said:
Man is but a sheath for his heart / And there is no good in a sheath if there is no blade.
If blights gather, stinginess is their secret / And worse than stinginess are broken promises and delay.

Another said:

I spread to Amr some of what is in my ribs / And I made him gulp the bitterness of what I gulp.
There must be a complaint to one of preservation / When the secrets of my soul begin to appear.

Abu Al-Aswad said:
Not every possessor of mind gives you his advice / And not every giver of advice is wise.
But when they gather in a companion / Then he has a right to a share of obedience.

Abu Al-Tamhan Al-Qayni said:
My son, if a conqueror imposes injustice upon you / A mighty one, then some humiliation is more lasting and abundant.
Do not protect yourself from some matters out of pride / For assumed pride may inherit long humiliation.

Abu Uthman Al-Mazini said:
If the traits of a man please you / Be him, and there will be in you what pleases you.
There is no veil over generosity and noble deeds / If you come to it, it veils you.
It is wealth; if you do not gain it / Time provides for you what deprives you.

Abu Hilal Al-Asadi said:
Leave the bad client and time alone / For its days and calamities will suffice you against him.
He meets an enemy other than you who returns him / To you, so you meet him while his side has softened.

Ibn Harma said:
The advice of the compassionate becomes a disease / If you oppose the advice of the compassionate.
Leave the small matter and wrap it up / For the impregnation of the great is from the small.

Another said:
I am, even if your chests are sick / Seeking endurance, my chest is sound towards you.
The cousin of a man is he who strengthens his back / And protects his defect while he does not know.
The noble is he who honors a person in hardship / Despite what befell him, he does not honor the possessor of ease.
Bitterness did not change me from my nobility / Nor did my wealth or poverty shame my guests.

A Bedouin said:
I will grant my money to everyone who comes asking / And make it an endowment for the loan and the obligation.
Either a noble whose honor I protected with money / Or a mean one whose meanness I protected my honor from.

Another said:
Sometimes a man, if his money is little, sees / Doors of good but cannot [enter] them.
He has no stinginess, but his money / Falls short of them, while the stingy one wastes them.

Nahik bin Asaf said:
I saw people's lineage is equal / When the old lineage is mentioned.
But livelihoods distinguished them / So the possessor of money is the approached and the noble.

Al-Hussein bin Mutayr said:
Stick to your soul regarding many matters / For you have no soul after it to borrow.
Neither generosity is from the poverty of men nor richness / But it is the nature of men and their choice.
The world may deceive, so its rich becomes / Poor, and its poor becomes rich after misery.
How many a greedy one for a need does not attain it / And one despairing of it, its bringer of glad tidings comes to him.

Rabi'a Al-Raqqi said:
If a man does not seek a livelihood for himself / He complains of poverty or blames the friend and does it often.
He becomes a burden on the closest ones, and the ropes / Of relatives are about to be cut.
So travel in God's lands and seek richness / You will live wealthy or die and be excused.
The seeker of needs in every direction / Of people is none other than he who is serious and strives.

Another said:
If you become destitute in a land, leave it / And urge the fast camels to leave it.
Do not let your brother's luck in it deceive you / If your right hand is empty of its gift.
Your soul, win with it if you fear oppression / And leave the house; whoever wept for it will be sad.
For you will find land for land / But you will not find a soul other than it.

Hatim Al-Tai said:
That is because I do not antagonize their chiefs / Nor do I refrain from their harms.
I give to my beggar, and perhaps / I am tasked with what I cannot bear, so I bear it.

Abdullah bin Urwa said:
The youth loves much wealth, but / The youth's soul has a share of what he gathers.
I see a man weeping for him who died before him / And the death of the one weeping over him is near.

Ibn Muqbil said:
So replace and destroy, for wealth is a loan / So eat it with time which is its eater.
The easiest lost thing and the lightest perishing thing / To the tribe is he whose gift does not reach the tribe.

Miskin Al-Darimi said:
I cross the desert with the clumsy camel, amused / When the stars in the darkness are lamps.
God did not send down a matter to me that I hate / Except He will make for me after it a relief.

Al-Hudhayn bin Al-Mundhir Al-Raqashi said:
Noble deeds are not attained by a man / Who inherited noble deeds from a father then wasted them.

A soul commanded him to baseness and obscenity / And forbade him from seeking height, so he obeyed it.
And if he attains a noble thing from matters / The noble builds with it noble deeds, but he sold it.

Another said:
By the life of my father, the one starting my abandonment out of boredom / If he turns away, the paths have not narrowed on me.
I am not one to weep over the love of a companion / When a companion initiates cutting me off.
If I am not stricken except by whom I have cared for / And who did not care for me, calamities are easy on me.

Ibn Harma said:
The soul has times in which bonds are untied / And stingy souls become generous with money.
If a man does not benefit you while alive, his benefit / Is less when the stones are stacked upon him.
For what state does a man withhold his money? / Tomorrow is tomorrow, and death comes and goes.

Another said:
In gray hair I have a preacher if I accept preaching / And in experiences I have a forbidder and a deterrenter.
Whoever lives, days wear out his newness / And the two trustworthy ones, hearing and sight, betray him.

Another said:
If the head of the council is not a master / There is no good in whom the councils put forward.
How many a sayer 'What is with me, I saw you on foot?' / I said to him: 'Because you are a knight' (sarcasm).

Another said:
My two friends, I was pleased with time and it trained me / On lack at times and at times on abundance.
It did not increase except I increased giving to a seeker / Nor did it bite me except I bit on patience.

For Hatim Al-Tai:
I am shy of my companions if they see / The place of my hand from the side of the provisions, bald (empty).
I hold back my hand from reaching their hands / When we reach for a need together.
I spend the night lean-bellied, folding the entrails / Out of shyness, fearing blame if I fill myself.
For if you give your belly its request / And your private parts, they attain the utmost of all blame.

Another said:
Blessing whose shade lasted did not make us reckless / Nor did we stand crooked from the calamity.
Evil does not belittle us when it touches us / Nor do we complain much if the matter is heavy.

For Ibn Harma:
The seeker of a need did not attain the like of despair / If there was no success in it for a seeker.
I am a thrower behind my clan / Patient against the casting of enemies and calamities.

For Suhaym:
I saw the beloved not tiring of his speech / And it does not benefit the hated to show affection.

Al-Fadl bin Abdul Rahman:
Sympathy for the client, even if there is / Between him and you in some matters a blame.
Who is he whom the distant hope for his benefit / If he is not good to the relatives?

For Dirar bin Utba:
I love the thing then turn away from it / Fearing that there be talk about it.
We fear that it be said to us so we are disgraced / And we know what men are insulted by.

For another:
If you do not cease judging by suspicion and demanding / Based on suspicion, the suspicions of accidents will destroy you.

For another:
It is enough sadness that richness is impossible / For me, while I am fond of noble deeds.
By God, I did not settle in seeking height / But I strive for it and get cut off.

Al-Muqanna' Al-Kindi said:
If you are provided with wealth from spoils / Then grant your closest clan its surplus.
Save it for the defense of every calamity / Be gentle with its young and obey its elder.
Be forbearing if its fools act ignorantly against you / Until you return their ignorance with the virtue of your forbearance.
Know that you will not be their youth / Until you see the soft of characters as their easy one.

For a Bedouin:
If you wish a people, place generosity between them / And you, you will be safe from all you fear.
If calamities uncover a defect from you / The dress of generosity suffices you what is uncovered.

Al-A'war Al-Shanni:
I am not stingy against my cousin / With victory in calamities nor with a gift.
The most honorable my soul is to me / Is when my money is little in times of drought.
I have become not needing, in what / I tested of matters, to ask.
What falling short? Ma'add has known / And the morals of lowliness are among my traits (negated).
If a man falls short then passes / Over him forty (years) with men.
And he does not catch up with their good ones, leave him / He is not catching up in the other nights.

Al-Kumait bin Zaid said:
People were not cheated the like of their minds / Nor like it did a gainer gain earnings.
I saw the sweetness of water, if blocked / Drinking its turbidity suffices you for what is inevitable.
If there is no mount but spearheads / The carried one has no opinion but to ride them.

For Ibn Harma:

If a man has no reliance for me / I forgave and blamed the one that is more beautiful.
I hide my burden as much as I can, and only / I act coquettishly when I have someone to be coquettish to.

Al-Zubair bin Abdul Muttalib said:
If you are sending someone for a need / Send a wise man and do not advise him.
If a matter twists against you / Consult a wise man and do not disobey him.
Do not speak in a gathering ever / A speech if you have not counted it.
Attribute the speech to its people / For the document is in its attribution.
If a sincere advisor from you moves away one day / Do not move away from him and do not exclude him.
How many a youth whose mind is absent / While the eye may admire his figure.
And another whom you think ignorant / Brings you the matter from its gem.

For the brother of Al-Harith bin Hilliza:
Take the matter easy, you live in comfort / Rarely did I take it easy but it became easy.
Ask the days about their kings / Which milk the milch-camel milked from them.
Life is not all easy / Life is but plains and rugged terrain.
And calamities, how strange they are / For calamities have backs and bellies.
Perhaps eyes were cooled by a grief / Painful, from which eyes became hot.

For another:
We were worn out by a time whose like people have not seen / It gave us to drink, upon baseness, the poison of vipers.
So a praiser for favor is not finding (favor) / And a finder of what he wills is not deviating (from evil).

Narrated for Abdul Malik bin Marwan:
You thought well of days when they were good / And did not fear the evil of what fate brings.
The nights made peace with you so you were deceived by them / And when nights are clear, turbidity occurs.

Al-Tawzi said:
I sifted my opinions and drove my advice / To one not open to the advisor nor cheerful.
When he refused my advice, I followed his path / And expanded for him false speech and deception.

For a man from Dabba:
The youth wishes noble deeds would come to him... / If he did a favor, he increased and completed.
It is not... when its building is complete / You follow it with reduction until it is demolished.

Al-Ahnaf bin Qais said:
And one with a tilted cheek (arrogant), I straightened the saying from him / With forbearance... upon the speech.
Whoever is forbearing and has no fool (to defend him) / Meets dilemmas from men.

For another:
I rose above insulting the clan, for I / Saw my father refrained from insulting them before me.
Forbearing when forbearance is his majesty / And ignorant (violent) sometimes when they seek my ignorance.

For Shabib bin Uqba:
May God tend to a time whose excuse justice silenced / In the prime of youth, whose purity turbidity did not mix.
I attain desires in it without blame / And no blame in a thing if the excuse is clear.

For Abu Al-Ghoul Al-Tahawi:
We found people to be two sticks: A good one / And a bad stick that does not break (give water) on breaking.
His morals adorn the youth and shame him / And the morals of the youth are mentioned where he does not know.

Amr bin Al-Mubarak said:
I will thank you for a favor you intended / Indeed, your concern for the favor is a favor.
I do not blame you if fate did not execute it / For the thing turned away by fate is turned away.

Adi bin Al-Riqa' said:
People are likes, and between their minds / Is a difference; likewise is the disparity of things.
Like the cloud, from it is continuous pouring rain / And generosity, and another does not give water.
Man, his glory is revived by his sons / And another dies while he is among the living.

For a man from Hudhayl:
Repair some of the matter with some / Indeed the fat carries the lean.
The eye sees preference between men / And in what they concealed is the clear preference.
Like the color of water, similar, and / Eyes do not inform about its taste.
So do not hasten with your thought before news / For at the news, thoughts are cut off.

Hatim said:
I am chaste in poverty, sharing in richness / A leaver of a shape that my shape does not suit.
My shape is a shape that its like is not upheld / Among people except by every possessor of generosity like me.
I have a fastidiousness in generosity and giving that / No one before me among those who passed appreciated.

Tufayl Al-Ghanawi said:
Women are like trees that grew together / From them is the bitter, and some bitter is eaten.
Women, whenever they are forbidden from a trait / It is obligatory, inevitably done.
Whatever evil they promised you, they fulfill it / And what they promised of good things is misleading.

For Hatim:
Do not blame me for what has passed / The changes of time are sufficient as a judge for a man.
Do not humiliate him who loves the lands, for / If he dies, the wealth will be plunder divided.

Be forbearing with the closest ones and keep their love / You will not be able to be forbearing until you dream (act forbearing).
And a defect I turned away from so it did not harm / And a crooked one I straightened so he became straight.
